Type 'help [keyword]' to get help on a specific keyword. Type `help list` to get a list of all the help entries. Some topics you could get help on is communication, combat, skills, and training.

Type 'newbie [text]' to ask or answer questions on the newbie channel. Type 'say [text]' to speak to the current room. Type 'whisper [text]' to speak to the current room without unhiding. Type 'tell [playername] [text]' to talk to an individual player. Type 'yell [text]' to yell a message to the current area. Type 'pray [text]' to send a message to the gods.

Type 'consider [name]' to see how an NPC's level compares to your own. Type 'kill [name]' to initiate combat with a creature. Some NPCs are aggressive and will attack you when you walk in. Type the name of a skill to perform it in combat if applicable, for example 'kick' while already fighting to perform your kick move. Mages can 'cast [spellname] [target]' to use their spells. Bards can 'sing [song name]' to sing their songs during combat.

New 'bug' command to report bugs to the gods. New 'map' command to draw an ascii map of the surrounding area. Typing 'help' now has a default help entry. 'Toggle' command to change flags such as Auto Loot, or Color Check out the website https:\\\\kbs-cloud.com for a map and more duelchallenge - Issue a duel challenge to another player. duelaccept - Accept a duel challenge from another player. duelcancel - Decline a duel challenge from another player. AFK flag added. No longer get hungry or thirsty after being inactive for five minutes. Typing `help list` will list all help entries Map now displays trainers, shops and healers.

You can type 'practice' to see a list of all skills, spells and songs you can currently use. Type 'practice [skill/spell/song]' at a guildmaster to learn an ability better. You can type 'skills', 'spells', 'songs' or 'supplications' to see a list of all the abilities you will ever learn. Mages use 'cast [ability]' to cast spells. Priestly guilds use 'commune [ability]' to use their prayers. Bards use 'sing [ability]' to sing their repertoire of songs.

You can train at a trainer or in some cases, at your guildmaster. You start with base stats for your race. These are strength, intelligence, wisdom, dexterity, constitution and charisma. These stats affect multiple aspects such as how much(weight/count) you can carry, how much you learn when practicing and how many hitpoints you will gain when you level. Type 'train' at a trainer to get a list of what is available to you to train. Each race has maximum values a stat can be raised to. You can type 'gain convert' to convert 10 practices into a train. You can type 'gain revert' to revert a train into 10 practices. You start with 3 trains and gain 1 train every 5 levels.

Helps.Help:
warrior - focus on weapon specialization, decent at taking and dealing damage. Gets a weapon specialization at level 20 and 40. Must be proficient in use of a weapon to specialize in it. Can shield block, dodge, parry and feint blows.
assassin - focus on martial arts, gets improved kicks upon mastering earlier ones. Can dodge and parry. Can bind wounds when injured.
mage - focus on perfecting elements. Unlock new elemental spells as you master earlier spells.
shapeshifter - focus on changing into the forms of animals. First form at level 5 - 8, must have a shapefocus major chosen.
thief - great at subterfuge, does better as a sidekick someone else standing in the fore. Can knock enemies out and bind their hands and legs. Can hide and sneak past some enemies and pick locks to open doors and containers.
healer - great at cleansing maladies and restoring the health of their friends. Can grant flight, sanctuary, blessings and a battle frenzy.
paladin - known for taking lead and standing in the fore of combat. They can grant themselves sanctuary. Choose whether to do more damage using a two handed weapon or block damage with a one handed weapon and a shield.
bard - boost the morale and health of your party, dash the spirits of your foes and cause them harm with offensive lyrics.
ranger - excel in the forests, caves, mountains and deserts of the world. Find and gather herbs for yourself or your party members to heal wounds. Take cover hiding yourself and ambush your prey in the wild. Explore the wilds, getting less tired as you move through them. Can fashion their own weapons in the wild and eventually be able to imbue them, causing them to heal during combat.

Good: Characters who are aligned with "good" believe in altruism, respect for life, and a desire to help others. They tend to make choices that benefit not just themselves but also those around them, often at their own expense. Good characters are compassionate and will often go out of their way to prevent harm to innocents. They uphold values of kindness, charity, and self-sacrifice.
Neutral: Neutral characters tend to be more pragmatic and do not feel a strong pull towards either extreme of good or evil. Their actions may be driven by personal gain, a sense of balance, or the specific situation at hand rather than an inherent moral code. Neutral characters might believe in a natural balance and might act to restore that balance if they feel it's been disrupted. They may also prioritize their own well-being or the well-being of their close companions over broader ethical or moral considerations.
Evil: Characters who are "evil" prioritize their own needs and desires over those of others and may be willing to harm or manipulate others to achieve their goals. They might be driven by greed, power, anger, hatred, or a desire for revenge. Evil characters might not necessarily be cruel or violent, but they tend to lack empathy for others, especially if there's a conflict between their interests and the well-being of others. It's worth noting that these alignments serve as broad categories, and within them, there can be a lot of variation. For example, one "good" character might be driven by a strong sense of justice, while another might prioritize mercy. Similarly, an "evil" character could be a ruthless tyrant or a cunning manipulator. The alignment system helps players think about their characters' motivations and can guide decision-making within the game, but it's always up to individual interpretation.
Good and evil characters receive bonus experience for slaying a character of the opposite alignment.

Lawful (often referred to as Orderly): Characters with a lawful alignment believe in a structured society, rules, order, and tradition. They value discipline, responsibility, and adherence to a set code of behavior, whether personal or dictated by a governing body. Lawful characters might respect authority, keep their promises, and try to always act within the confines of the law. Their predictability is both a strength and a weakness. It's important to note that "lawful" doesn't necessarily mean "good"; a character can be lawful and evil, adhering strictly to a code or set of laws that are oppressive or harmful.
Neutral (with respect to ethos): Neutral characters, in terms of ethos, fall between the extremes of lawfulness and chaos. They might respect order and authority when it suits them or their goals but don't inherently adhere to them. Similarly, they don't actively seek to disrupt order or sow chaos. Their actions are often driven by what seems appropriate at the moment, making them flexible and pragmatic. They tend to prioritize personal freedom and will generally go with whatever system or approach offers them the best balance of security and freedom.
Chaotic: Chaotic characters value individual freedom over structure and order. They are skeptical of authority and often resist rules, regulations, and traditions, seeing them as constraints. They prioritize personal freedom and often act based on their whims or personal desires rather than any external code of behavior. Like with the lawful alignment, "chaotic" does not inherently mean "evil"; a chaotic good character, for example, might defy oppressive laws to do what they believe is right.

Syntax: prompt Syntax: prompt default Syntax: prompt all same as `prompt default` Syntax: prompt <%*>
PROMPT with out an argument will turn your prompt on or off.
PROMPT ALL will give you the standard "<hits mana moves>" prompt.
PROMPT <%*> where the %* are the various variables you may set yourself. %1 : Display % of hitpoints %2 : Display % of mana %3 : Display % of movement %h : Display your current hits %H : Display your maximum hits %m : Display your current mana %M : Display your maximum mana %v : Display your current moves %V : Display your maximum moves %x : Display your current experience %X : Display experience to level %g : Display your gold held %s : Display silver carried %a : Display your alignment %r : Display the room name you are in %e : Display the exits from the room in NESWDU style %c : Display a carriage return (useful for multi-line prompts) %R : Display the vnum you are in (IMMORTAL ONLY) %z : Display the area name you are in (IMMORTAL ONLY)
Example: PROMPT <%hhp %mm %vmv> Will set your prompt to "<10hp 100m 100mv>"
